posts.title: More than 100 children fall sick after dead snake reportedly found in school lunch in India
top_comments: India's human rights commission is investigating an incident in which more than 100 children became sick after eating a school lunch contaminated by a dead snake at a government-run school in Mokama, Bihar. Forager here! She was trying to set it up as an accidental poisoning. This detail may not strike you if you're not in the hobby, but the article mentions she first claimed that she bought foraged mushrooms from an Asian grocer.

Asian immigrants often enjoy foraging. When they move to other continents, they wind up poisoned by death cap mushrooms at a statistically higher rate than other groups. This is because our death caps look very similar to mushrooms edible in their home country. It's so common that immigration officials should put something on immigration forms about how edible mushrooms on X country may easily be confused with deadly mushrooms from Y country.

But anyways, clearly this woman researched poisoning with this mushroom in particular. And was trying to create plausible deniability by blaming immigrants.

What the fuck is that headline?

This would have gotten an instant F and a “try again” in any class when I was in school and we’re talking about a campus newspaper read by a few thousand people.

We non-poisoners are extremely lucky that science has finally evolved to where poisons can be generally identified and traced post-mortem. It's extremely hard to get away with poisoning in modern societies now. Including from mushrooms. But in other societies, it's still rampant.

I'm most familiar with it in the pan-African context, but I presume it's common worldwide, until the science catches up. Poisoning was a common event in my best friend/collaborator's life in the Samburu tribe (a Maasai subgroup) in rural Kenya, and features prominently in the story of her childhood we did. I've seen it repeatedly in other African novels and memoirs as well, off the top of my head Adichie's "Purple Hibiscus" (Nigeria, west Africa) and Trevor Noah's "Born a Crime" (South Africa).

We're honestly very, very fortunate that the threat of actually being caught is becoming a true deterrence. Even this lady had to "cook up" some excuse as to why she had poison mushrooms in the dish: she realized she might be traced.
I love that the drawing makes her look like a character out of Common Side Effects.
